document.docTitle: Nesodiprion flavipes Hara & Smith, 2015, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Japanese species of the sawfly genus Nesodiprion (Hymenoptera, Diprionidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Japanese species of the sawfly genus Nesodiprion (Hymenoptera, Diprionidae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Ovipositor sheath as in
Figs 14 J–K
. Lance as in Figs 15 G–H. Lancet (Figs 16 E–F) with 11 annuli, widest around fifth annulus, nearly pointed at apex with length from apex to ventral end of first row of spines 3.6–3.7 [ 3.7 ] × maximum width; first row of spines oblique and dorsally curved, with its ventral end separated from ventral margin of lancet; first annulus without serrula; serrulae of second to fifth annuli simple; sixth to more posterior annuli posteriorly angularly convex.

caption.paragraph:

N japonicus
(H, male) and
N. shinoharai

subSubSection.paragraph: Dorsum of abdomen scarcely punctured posteriorly.

Etymology . The species name is from the Latin flavus + pes , meaning yellow legs or yellow feet, referring to the almost entirely yellow legs of the species.

Host plant . Pinaceae :
Tsuga diversifolia (Maxim.) Mast.

Life history . In mountainous regions in Honshu, one female was collected in late July, and larvae were found in late August to middle September. Larvae are yellow orange and feed gregariously on needles (Kojima, personal communication, 2015 ).

Remarks .
Nesodiprion flavipes
is easily distinguished from other congeners by the almost entirely yellow legs. Although the male of
N. shinoharai
has almost entirely yellow and orange legs, these two belong to different species groups and are easily distinguished as in the key below.
